Problem:
Analyze the heat distribution in a rod over time governed by the heat equation \\( \\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} = k \\frac{\\partial^2 u}{\\partial x^2} \\), where \\( u(x,t) \\) is the temperature at position x and time t, and k is the thermal diffusivity coefficient. Consider an intervention where a heating element applies a periodic thermal function \\( p(x) = \\sin(\\omega x) \\) at a specific location along the rod.

If the initial heat distribution is set as \\( u(x,0) = \\sin(\\pi x) \\) and evolves under the heat equation without any other influences, will the heat distribution profile at a later time t be solely dependent on the initial function and thermal diffusivity k?
Explanation: In the absence of external influences, the heat distribution over time will depend only on the initial function \\( u(x,0) \\) and the parameter k through the heat equation. Dispersal patterns will be determined entirely by diffusion according to the governing equation.
